#### **Basic Op-Amp**

![](l6-1-operational-amplifier-img/basic-op-amp.png){#fig-basic-op-amp align=center width=300 alt="basic-op-amp.png"}

Operational amplifier or op-amp:

- Very high gain differential amplifier (A = $10^5$ - $10^6$)
- High input impedance (typically a few meg-Ohms)
- Low output impedance ( >100 )
- Used for feedback circuits
- They have a differential input

##### Differential Input

- The output depends on the difference of 2 inputs. Here:

$$V_o = A_v (V^+ - V^-)$$

- This contrasts with a single entity input, which is just 1 wire

**Note the op-amp has two inputs and one output.**

{3}------------------------------------------------

#### Op-Amp Gain

##### Videos

{{< video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P644hjOwbV0 >}}

##### Uni notes

**Op-Amps have a very high gain. They can be connected open-loop or closed-loop.**

- **Open-loop refers to a configuration where there is no feedback from output back to the input. In the open-loop configuration the gain can exceed 10,000.**
- **Closed-loop configuration reduces the gain. In order to control the gain of an opamp it must have feedback. This feedback is a negative feedback. A negative feedback reduces the gain and improves many characteristics of the op-amp.**

## Inverting Op-Amp

![](_page_6_Picture_1.jpeg){width=300 align=center}

- The signal input is applied to the inverting (–) input
- The non-inverting input (+) is grounded
- The resistor Rfis the feedback resistor. It is connected from the output to the negative (inverting) input. This is *negative feedback*.

{7}------------------------------------------------

### **Inverting Op-Amp Gain**

Gain can be determined from external resistors: R<sub>f</sub> and R<sub>1</sub>

$$Voltage\ Gain = A_v = \frac{V_o}{V_i} = -\frac{R_f}{R_1}$$

Unity gain—voltage gain is 1

$$\mathbf{R}_{r} = \mathbf{R}_{r}$$

$$A_{v} = \frac{-R_{f}}{R_{1}} = -1$$

The negative sign denotes a $180^\circ$ phase shift between input and output.

### **Example:**

**EXAMPLE 5** If the circuit of Fig. 34 has  $R_1 = 100 \text{ k}\Omega$  and  $R_f = 500 \text{ k}\Omega$ , what output voltage results for an input of  $V_1 = 2 \text{ V}$ ?

![](_page_8_Picture_2.jpeg){width=300 align=center}

![](_page_8_Picture_3.jpeg){width=300 align=center}

FIG. 34: Inverting constant-gain multiplier.

Solution:

$$V_o = -\frac{R_f}{R_1} V_1 = -\frac{500 \,\mathrm{k}\Omega}{100 \,\mathrm{k}\Omega} (2 \,\mathrm{V}) = -10 \,\mathrm{V}$$

> The formula used above is from the definition of gain, $A_v = \frac{V_o}{V_i} = - \frac{R_f}{R_i}$

{9}------------------------------------------------

**EXAMPLE 5** If the circuit of Fig. 34 has  $R_1 = 100 \,\mathrm{k}\Omega$  and  $R_f = 500 \,\mathrm{k}\Omega$ , what output voltage results for an input of  $V_1 = 2 \,\mathrm{sin} \,\mathrm{wt} \,\mathrm{V}$ ?

![](_page_9_Figure_2.jpeg){width=300 align=center}

FIG. 34

Inverting constant-gain multiplier.

Solution:

$$V_o = -\frac{R_f}{R_1} V_1 = -\frac{500 \,\mathrm{k}\Omega}{100 \,\mathrm{k}\Omega} (2 \,\mathrm{sin}\,\mathrm{wt}\,\mathrm{V}) = -10 \,\mathrm{sin}\,\mathrm{wt}\,\mathrm{V}$$

# Virtual Ground

## Videos

{{< video https://youtu.be/AuZ00cQ0UrE?si=ZL0a8mXwKJ8FVcbA&t=229 >}}

## Uni Notes

An understanding of the concept of virtual ground provides a better understanding of how an opamp operates.

The *non-inverting* input pin is at ground. *The inverting*  input pin is also at 0 V for an AC signal.

The op-amp has such high input impedance that even with a high gain there is no current from inverting input pin, therefore there is no voltage from inverting pin to ground—all of the current is through R<sup>f</sup>.

## Inverting/Noninverting Op-Amps

> The placement of resistors on the negative terminal of the op-amp is used to stabilize the output and the negative feedback is used to amplify the output

### Inverting Amplifier

$$V_0 = \frac{-R_f}{R_1} V_1$$

![](_page_11_Picture_3.jpeg){width=300 align=center}

### Noninverting Amplifier

$$V^0 = (1 + \frac{R_f}{R_1})V^1$$

- They are used because they have high input impedance and other characteristics of an op-amp


$$V_0 = V_1$$

## Summing Amplifier

Because the op-amp has a high input impedance, the multiple inputs are treated as separate inputs.

![](_page_14_Figure_3.jpeg){width=300 align=center}

$$V_o = -\left(\frac{R_f}{R_1}V_1 + \frac{R_f}{R_2}V_2 + \frac{R_f}{R_3}V_3\right)$$

# Integrator

- The output is the integral of the input
- Integration is the operation of summing the area under a waveform or curve over a period of time
- Useful in lowpass filter circuits and sensor conditioning circuits

$$v_o(t) = -RC \int v_1(t)dt$$

![](_page_17_Figure_3.jpeg){width=300 align=center}

{18}------------------------------------------------

# Differentiator

The differentiator takes the derivative of the input. This circuit is useful in high-pass filter circuits.

$$v_o(t) = -RC \frac{dv_1(t)}{dt}$$

![](_page_18_Picture_3.jpeg){width=300 align=center}
